steps.title: Statement
steps.statement: If $a_n \to L$ and $a_n \to M$ as $n \to \infty$, then $L = M$.
steps.justification: A single sequence cannot converge to two different real numbers.
steps.insight: We again use the Îµ-definition to reach a contradiction.

steps.title: Contradiction setup
steps.insight: This makes the neighborhoods around $L$ and $M$ disjoint.

steps.title: Convergence to both limits
steps.statement: There exist $N_1, N_2$ such that $n \ge N_1 \Rightarrow |a_n - L| < \varepsilon$ and $n \ge N_2 \Rightarrow |a_n - M| < \varepsilon$.
steps.insight: Large enough indices land inside both bands.

steps.title: Pick a common index
steps.statement: Let $N = \max\{N_1, N_2\}$ and take $n \ge N$. Then both bounds hold at once.
steps.justification: A single $n$ satisfies both convergence conditions.
steps.insight: The term $a_n$ must sit in the overlap.

steps.title: Contradiction and conclusion
steps.statement: Triangle inequality gives $|L - M| \le |L - a_n| + |a_n - M| < \varepsilon + \varepsilon = |L - M|$, impossible. Hence $L = M$.
steps.justification: The strict inequality contradicts the assumed gap.
